awd_titl_txt: SCC-PG: Building Community Response to Violence through the Rokwire Smart City Platform
awd_abstract_narration:
This project builds upon a highly interdisciplinary and well-connected team of researchers and stakeholders from across the University of Illinois in Urbana-Champaign (UIUC) and the local Champaign-Urbana community. Through a series of stakeholder meetings and community outreach, our team will explore and define challenges, barriers, and opportunities for deploying and modifying technology to address community violence. Our investigation will focus on social science issues, such as how best to design smartphone apps to reduce violence, as well as technological issues, such as how to assure data privacy so that users do not risk revealing their identities at any stage of the research and community activity process. 

This project investigates the creation and scalability of the smart community concept by bringing together a team of engineers, social and behavioral scientists, and a community partner - the municipal government of the City of Champaign - to leverage an open-source digital platform, the Rokwire Smart City Platform, and build an integrative community response to violence. Rokwire is an open-source mobile software platform developed by Smart, Healthy Communities, an interdisciplinary initiative based at UIUC. Designed to be the open-source system for tomorrow’s smart communities, it is a mobile ecosystem that puts people and privacy first while combining multiple streams of data and sensor technologies and integrating that information into a single, open-source platform. This project is proposing to design the coverage and functionality of Rokwire with the local community, and in particular, the City of Champaign, which has a violent crime rate of double the national average, to create functionalities in Rokwire that serve the community’s desire to reduce violence. Our long-term goal is to use this effort as a testbed for interested communities country-wide. The planning grant will seek to address timely research questions in the social science and technological dimensions. In the social science dimension, this project will build Rokwire to create, together with the City of Champaign, a violence reporting, tracking, and intervention capacity for Rokwire that will a) be designed with community input to evaluate the prevalence of, and reduce, violence in Champaign and b) work with the community to investigate and minimize unintended consequences (e.g., racial profiling, victim-blaming) associated with violence reporting technology. In the technological dimension, this project will address pressing questions relating to communities and researchers extracting useful and informative data while preserving individual privacy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project had several key outcomes.

First, we created and nurturned many community connections. Namely, we immersed ourselves in the community and conducted over 50 interviews with community members affected by gun violence and community organizations within the gun violence prevention and response ecosystem. For example, we talked with leaders at youth development organizations (e.g., Don Moyer Boys and Girls Club), advocacy groups (e.g., Moms Demand Action), City Leaders (e.g., from the Cities of Champaign and Urbana), school districts (e.g., Unit 4), and individuals directly affected by gun violence. We also attended community events and conducted secondary research on gun violence reduction efforts.

Second, we systematically organized the notes from the community immersion into potential ?opportunity areas? of community needs, presented the synthesized research findings back to our community stakeholders to verify our understanding of the community?s needs, and gained initial feedback on the opportunity area?s directions. We then iteratively generated potential solutions within each opportunity area and created lo-fi prototypes of what each technological solution may entail. We then presented the solution concepts to our community stakeholders to get their feedback and input (Figure 1). We then made a collective decision on which concept to pursue by evaluating each concept?s a) potential impact, b) risks and limitations, c) leverage of community assets, and d) sustainability and scalability. Our team of citizen scientists and academic researchers unanimously decided to create an E-mentoring platform that connects existing networks of community mentors with mentees and features specific tools that meet their needs. 

Third, we engaged youth from our community in the technology development process and engaged in meaningful upskilling. We engaged with youth in the community by working with them to understand their needs and experiences specifically within the mentoring (and potentially E-mentoring) space. This occurred via focused user-experience research sessions that took place in the summers of 2022 and 2023, working with over 15 different youth and their key community mentors. In addition, in the summer of 2023, we helped fund a small cohort of 6 youth to participate in the School of Engineering?s People Designing for People bootcamp, to help develop their capabilities as citizen science designers and spur their interest in technology development. 

Fourth, we communicated our work and findings at two conferences, are in the process of prepairing a manuscript that documented our community-engaged research process, and will soon submit an NSF S&CC IRG proposal based on our research. 

 


Last Modified: 10/19/2023
Modified by: Sanjay J Patel
